questions.text: The given sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is caused by ________
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in trachoma caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction
  • Seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitots spot in bulbar conjunctiva

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori) causing type B gastritis.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

Type B gastritis 

  • Type B gastritis is associated with H. pylori.
  • It commonly affects the antrum.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is associated with chronic pan-gastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential.

H. pylori infection is also a risk factor for the following:

  • Peptic ulcer disease (duodenal > gastric)
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma
  • Gastric lymphoma

Image: Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium.

Image: Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Uses
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen- positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal-cell carcinoma)
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin

questions.text: All of the following are true about the scientist who performed the given experiment except :

choices.text: He developed the concept of learning by association
He developed the theory of classical conditioning
He studied the physiology of digestion
He gave the model for operant conditioning

questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. 

The theory of operant conditioning was given by Skinner.

 Ivan Pavlov's contributions:

  • Classical conditioning, which is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning.
  • Work on the physiology of digestion.
  • Classical conditioning by Pavlov: The theory of learning in which a natural response (salivation) is elicited by a conditioned or learned stimulus (bell), that was previously presented with an unconditioned stimulus (food).

Operant conditioning by Skinner: It is a method of learning that occurs through rewards and punishments for behavior.

Related Pearl: Scientists and their contributions to psychiatry

SCIENTIST
CONTRIBUTIONS
Erik Erikson
Theory of psychosocial development
Jean Piaget
Theory of cognitive development
Kurt Schneider
First rank symptoms of schizophrenia
Ivan Pavlov
Classical conditioning
B. F. Skinner
Operant conditioning
Kubler Ross
Described stages/ model of death
Abraham Maslow
Described hierarchy of needs
Alfred Adler
Founder of Individual psychology coined the term Inferiority complex
Adolf Meyer 
Father of Psychobiology
Roger Wolcott Sperry
Split Brain concept
Cerletti and Binni
Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
Johann Reil
Coined the term psychiatry
Emil Kraepelin
Coined the term dementia praecox
Hecker
Coined the term hebephrenia
Kahlbaum
Coined the term catatonia
Eugene Bleuler
Coined the term schizophrenia
Carl Jung
Coined the term analytical psychology, extrovert, introvert

questions.text:
The device shown in the image given below is used in.

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • I-125 and Iridium-192 - used in low dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 - is used for high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist, or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources while administration. It provides protection from radiation exposure to healthcare professionals by securing the radiation source in a shielded safe manner.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a fasciotomy of the lower limb.

Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, fat and fascia. The muscle will be seen bulging out through the fasciotomy opening. The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia. This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more is its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • The more the curve is on the left side, the more is its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless beefy-red ulcer on the labia that bleeds when touched. There is no lymphadenopathy. Microscopic findings are as shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy, with microscopy showing Donovan bodies, points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale. It is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis also known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

The image below shows a beefy-red ulcer characteristic of donovanosis.

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.

Prolonged treatment with antibiotics is generally advised for donovanosis, usually for a minimum period of 6 weeks.

Treatment ladder for Donovanosis

  • First line
    • Azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily
  • Second line
    • Doxycycline 100 mg orally on the first day followed by 100 mg twice daily (or) 
    • Co‐trimoxazole 960 mg twice daily

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design.
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case–control study. The study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

This is the first approach to test causal hypothesis and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: The cell seen in pap smear is ______
questions.solution:
The above cell in PAP smear is progesterone-dependent. 

Identified by :- 

  • Progesterone dominant: Smear shows intermediate cells (Basophillic with haphazard shape and pyknotic nucleus) and navicular cells, dirty smear.
  • Oestrogen dominant: Clean smear with acidophillic cells (pink), polygonal in shape
  • Human papiloma infected: Koilocytes with perinuclear halo and peripheral condensation of cytoplasm
  • After menopause: PAP is predominantly filled with basal and parabasal cells.

In the image below :

(a) Normal squamous, (b) Intermediate squamous, (c) Columnar, (d) Mild dysplasia, (e) Moderate dysplasia, (f) Severe dysplasia, and (g) Carcinoma in situ.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with a fever for 3 days associated with chills, rigors and multiple painless lesions on palms as below.  He has a history of prosthetic valve surgery and cardiac auscultation shows a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region. Which of the following is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Sydenham's chorea is a late-stage manifestation of rheumatic fever, not infectious endocarditis.

Fever PLUS a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region with a history of prosthetic valve surgery is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis.

The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices.

Risk factors for Infectious Endocarditis (IE):

  • Age >60 years
  • Male sex
  • Injection drug use
  • Poor dentition, dental infection or inadequate antimicrobial microbial prophylaxis
  • Structural heart disease
  • Valvular disease
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Prosthetic heart valves
  • History of IE
  • Intravascular devices
  • Implantable cardiac devices
  • Transcatheter aortic valve replacement
  • Chronic hemodialysis
  • HIV infection

Clinical features of left-sided endocarditis include:

  • Fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain and arthralgias
  • Cardiac murmurs, valvular insufficiency, heart failure
  • Splenomegaly, splenic infarction, renal infarction, glomerulonephritis
  • Embolic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and abscesses
  • Peripheral manifestations

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding.
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits.
  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles.
  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers.

An image showing Roth's spots which are exudative hemorrhagic lesions.

An image showing Janeway lesions.

An image showing Osler's nodes.

A clinical image of splinter hemorrhages, which should prompt suspicion for infective endocarditis :

Treatment of infective endocarditis
Streptococci Penicillin with gentamicin
Staphylococcus aureus infecting native valve Vancomycin
Staphylococcus aureus infecting prosthetic valves Vancomycin +gentamicin +rifampin
Enterococci Ampicillin with gentamicin
HACEK group Ceftriaxone or ampicillin with sulbactam
Coxiella burnetti Doxycycline with hydroxychloroquine
Bartonella Doxycycline with gentamicin

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

 Condition

Most common organism

Most common organism overall

Staphylococcus aureus

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side) Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side) Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Single most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organism causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (>12 months after surgery)

Streptococci

 

Acute infective endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Subacute infective endocarditis

Streptococcus viridans

Enterococci

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)

HACEK

Cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)-associated endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus  and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)*

Culture negative endocarditis

Prior antibiotic use

Nutritionally variant streptococci

HACEK organisms

Coxiella burnetii

Bartonella

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

 

Microorganism

Source

Streptococcus viridans

Oral cavity

Staphylococcus aureus

Skin

HACEK organisms

Upper respiratory tract

Streptococcus gallolyticus

GIT (Colon )

Enterococci

Genitourinary tract

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

Related Pearl: Cartilages of Larynx

Unpaired Cartilages
Paired Cartilages
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Epiglottis
  • Arytenoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform

 

Hyaline
Fibroelastic

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury.What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The image is of battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process.

Middle Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Anterior Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: The X-ray given below is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows folds that run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen, which is called a feline esophagus and is seen in reflux esophagitis. 

Feline oesophagus is also known as oesophageal shiver, refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower oesophagus on a double contrast barium swallow. The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux and is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae with resultant shortening of the oesophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

Radiologic features: The folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oesophageal lumen. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic oesophagus.

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic oesophagitis (wherein the folds will be permanent and be associated with strictures).

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: The image shown below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exclamation mark hair sign which is a characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes nonscarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients.

The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with telogen effluvium demonstrate empty follicles and regrowing hairs of normal thickness on dermoscopy.

Option C: Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with this disease present with lustreless, dry, short hair. On trichoscopy, patients may have a characteristic bamboo hair defect due to the collapse of the distal hair shaft into the proximal hair shaft secondary to defective keratinization.

Option D: Primary cicatricial alopecias are inflammatory disorders that lead to permanent hair loss

questions.text: A female patient visits the OPD with complaints of swelling around her eye as shown in the image. Which of the following transmits the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image above is Romana’s sign. It is seen in acute Chagas disease which is caused by the flagellate Trypanosoma cruzi. It is transmitted by the Reduviid bug.

The person can become infected if T. cruzi parasites in the bug feces enter the body through mucous membranes or breaks in the skin. The sleeping person may accidentally scratch or rub the feces into the bite wound, eyes, or mouth. 

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

The chronic phase is characterized by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This may lead to congestive heart failure presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with proteinuria, and hemoptysis, with the following clinical presentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows saddle nose deformity, which occurs due to the destruction of the nasal septum. A history of proteinuria and hemoptysis along with the saddle nose deformity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic sinusitis, serous otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage, nasal septal perforation, and mucosal ulceration of the nasopharynx.
  • Lower respiratory tract: presenting with cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and persistent pneumonitis. Lung involvement typically appears as multiple, bilateral nodular cavitary infiltrates.
  • Kidneys: focal or segmental glomerulonephritis presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. If left untreated it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Apart from these organs, it can also affect the eyes and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Lab investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. Chest radiograph will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from the lungs, upper airways, skin, and rarely in the kidneys. HPE shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and veins together with either intravascular or extravascular granuloma formation. Chronic nasal carriage of Staphylococcus aureus is associated with a higher relapse rate. 

Options A: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. Severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates characterize the pulmonary findings. Renal disease is less common in these patients.

Option B: Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. it can present as a deformity on the nose and nasal perforation but is often accompanied by crusting. It is also accompanied by skin symptoms like anesthesia and nerve involvement

Option C: SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. Clinical features include a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash), oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a normal finding in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Image B shows buphthalmos, which is not a normal finding in a newborn. It is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and thus it should be investigated. The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (ox eye).

Features of congenital glaucoma:

  • Photophobia
  • Blepharospasm
  • Watering
  • Enlarged eyeball (buphthalmos)
  • Cloudy cornea > 1cm in diameter
  • Autosomal recessive disease
  • Definitive treatment involves surgical correction

Image A shows mongolian spots, and image C shows erythema toxicum. These both are normal findings.

questions.text: Name the procedure depicted in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts the nothern blotting technique.

Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.

Other blotting techniques :

  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: The prototype of the device shown here was first invented by
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the anesthesia workstation.

The prototype of this device is Boyle's machine which was first invented by Edmund Gaskin Boyle in 1917. 

Boyle’s machine, which is used to provide anesthesia, has evolved over the years into anesthetic workstations, which are currently in use.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presenting with halitosis and regurgitation, underwent a barium swallow scan as shown below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition​?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with halitosis and regurgitation with the GIF of an X-ray showing the barium swallow filling a sac in the posterior pharyngeal wall is highly suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describes the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters, and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis, and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back-fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic

Local reaction

  • severe
  • edema and necrosis

Anticoagulant effect - widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic

Local reaction

  • mild

Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (Sea snakes) are now considered subfamily of elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

questions.text: The below picture depicts ______
questions.solution:
The above picture depicts placenta with two lobes, hence the answer is placenta succenturiata.

Succenturiate Placenta

  • The second lobe is also known as the accessory lobe. 
  • Accessory lobe is attached to main lobe by membrane which has leash of blood vessels. 
  • A placenta containing three or more equally sized lobes is rare and termed multilobate.

Complication

  • Accessory lobe can be retained causing subinvolution, sepsis, Post-partum haemorrhage, vasa previa, fetal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing tortuous swelling over the scalp and the clinical findings are suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascuar occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a fracture of the right tibia following an RTA. Distal pulses could be felt well. The wound was highly contaminated and appeared as shown below. According to the Gustilo-Anderson classification,  the fracture would be classified as Type____________
questions.solution:
This wound will be classified as Type 3B on Gustilo-Anderson's classification due to the extensive wound (>10 cm), high contamination, severe loss of soft tissue cover and intact vascularity.

A fracture where the skin and soft tissues are breached is known as an open fracture (or a compound fracture). Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures. 

Gustilo and Anderson's classification for open injuries:

Type Wound Level of contamination Soft tissue injury Bone injury
I <1 cm Clean Minimal Simple, minimal comminution
II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery

Note: Open fractures with an arterial injury that requires repair will be classified as 3C, irrespective of the size of the soft-tissue wound.

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the image given below, all of the following can be found in the area marked 'x' except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises 1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: The image given below represents ______
questions.solution:
Image shows eliciting "Homan’s sign" i.e. calf tenderness on forced ankle dorsiflexion seen in DVT(deep venous thrombosis)

Other signs are:

  • Moses Sign - Calf tenderness on direct pressure on calf.
  • Pratt’s Sign - Calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen.
questions.solution:
The given image shows cribrifrom hymen because it has multiple small openings.

Based on the shape of its opening, the hymen may be classified as:

Hymen Description
Annular Oval central opening
Crescentric Semilunar central opening
Vertical Vertical slit-like opening
Septate 2 lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue
Cribriform Multiple small openings

Other variants of the hymen:

Variants Description
Absence of hymen Congenital deformity.
Infantile Small central linear opening.
Imperforated Without any opening
Fimbriated

The free margin of the hymenal opening shows symmetrical indentations or notches placed anteriorly.
Ring or fringe-like 

With a narrow ring or fringe or band of thick membrane all around the vaginal orifice (can easily distend during sexual intercourse without

rupturing the hymen)

Note:

  • The hymen is lined by stratified squamous epithelium on both sides.
  • The hymen is most commonly torn posterolaterally or posteriorly. 
  • It is replaced by tags after childbirth called as carunculae myrtiformes.

Other types of hymen are given in the image below:

questions.text: What is the sign represented by the image below called?
questions.solution:
The above image indicates the presence of Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm in patients experiencing hypocalcemia.

  • To elicit the sign, a blood pressure cuff is placed around the arm, inflated to a pressure greater than the systolic blood pressure, and held in place for 3 minutes.
  • This will occlude the brachial artery.
  • In the absence of blood flow, the patient's condition of hypocalcemia and subsequent neuromuscular irritability will induce spasm of the muscles of the hand and forearm.
  • This sign is also known as main d'accoucheur (French word for "hand of the obstetrician") because it supposedly resembles the position of an obstetrician's hand while delivering a baby.

Other options

Chvostek's sign

  • Seen in hypocalcemia
  • When the facial nerve is tapped in front of the tragus, the facial muscles on the same side of the face will contract momentarily (typically a twitch of the nose or lips) because of hypocalcemia.

Troisier's sign

  • Associated with left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal malignancy.

Lhermitte’s sign

  • Barber chair phenomenon - Electric shock-like sensation upon flexion of the neck observed, involving the posterior column.
  • Classically seen in association with multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: The image given below is used for the depiction of _______ of a disease in epidemiology.
questions.solution:
Spot maps are used to understand the local distributions of a disease.

Spot maps:

  • They are also called shaded maps.
  • They depict areas of high or low frequency, the boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution.
  • This method was used by John Snow to investigate the epidemic of cholera in London in 1854.
